org.mmbase.datatypes.processors

Class FormatQuantity

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.mmbase.datatypes.processors.FormatQuantity
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Processor
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    FormatFileSize, FormatQuantity.Parser

    public class FormatQuantity
extends Object
implements Processor
    A processor that gets a number as a file-size, that is, rounded with kbytes and Mb's and so on. Actually, using setters like setUnit(String), this class can also be used to postfix all other kinds of units to integers.
    Since:
    MMBase-1.9
    Version:
    $Id$
    Author:
    Michiel Meeuwissen
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • FormatQuantity

        public FormatQuantity()

    • Method Detail

      • setBinaryPrefixes

        public void setBinaryPrefixes(boolean bi)
        If set, will use binary prefixes as recommended by IEEE 1541. So, Ki, Mi, etc. which are multiples of 1024. Otherwise normal SI prefixes are applied (k, M, G etc), which are multiples of 1000.

      • setUnit

        public void setUnit(String u)
        The unit symbol which is prefixed by the prefixes. No unit on default.

      • getUnit

        public String getUnit()

      • setFormat

        public void setFormat(String mf)
        MessageFormat to format the number. Defaults to '0 '.
        Since:
        MMBase-1.9

      • getFormat

        public String getFormat()

      • setHighFormat

        public void setHighFormat(String mf)

        public void setLowFormat(String mf)

      • getLowFormat

        public String getLowFormat()

      • setLimit

        public void setLimit(int l)
        How big size / prefix must be to enter realm of next bigger prefix.
        Since:
        MMBase-1.9

      • setLowLimit

        public void setLowLimit(int l)
        For low numbers, sometimes a bit different pattern is desired. E.g. for number until 20 or so, you may want to show a decimal place. (14.3 KiB vs 64 KiB).

      • setInteger

        public void setInteger(boolean i)
        If a quantity is 'integer' then it can not have fractional values. For example a number of bytes.
        Since:
        MMBase-1.9.2
